div.p: This tag is found in WRITING PRODUCTION . This tag describes the physical and economic circumstances that governed a woman's writing or a particular text. This category is meant to answer questions like: did she have a room of her own? Was it the laundry room or a posh cabin on the French Riviera? Was she losing her eyesight while writing a particular work? Did she hide the manuscript while writing? This element encloses a full sentence or clause. It has no mandatory or optional sub-elements, but one optional attribute, DISPLACEMENT, with a value of DisplacementYes. This might signify migration, or moving out of her home because of marital troubles or failure to pay the rent.

div.codeblock: <PMATERIALCONDITIONS>The preface to Ann Grant's memoirs explains that they were written under "painful circumstances."</PMATERIALCONDITIONS>
It is still not known if Eliza Fenwick's second novel ever appeared <PMATERIALCONDITIONS>or if it was a casualty of stress and poverty.</PMATERIALCONDITIONS>

<PMATERIALCONDITIONS>Djuna Barnes wrote her novel while living at Hayford Hall under the auspices of Peggy Guggenhiem, who had rented the place. Several other writers were living there at the same time. </PMATERIALCONDITIONS>

div.p: This element differs from the CLASS and WEALTH categories in the BIOGRAPHY section of the entry in that it is specific to the conditions under which she wrote.

The element can be used to discuss emotional or health issues that affected the writing, or deadline pressures brought to bear by publishers, but these may sometimes be more accurately described using the PMOTIVES element. See PMOTIVES.
Question: Does the following example belong in PMATERIALCONDITIONS or in PMOTIVES? During the Irish famine, Elizabeth Grant wrote for bread mainly for others.
Answer: You might consider enclosing the whole sentence in PMOTIVES, while also putting a PMATERIALCONDITIONS element round the first four words.
